result.execSummary:
The defendant Reuben A. Rave III was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Endanger Safety/Use/Dangerous Weapon, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 941.20(1)(a).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: May apply for expungement after 2 years, if he pays his court ordered financial obligations and has no further criminal charges.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Reuben A. Rave III

records.addlTxt: from Goodman's Behavioral Health Clinic LLC
DA Fox appeared on behalf of the State.  Defendant appeared with  Attorney Matousek.
Plea hearing on October 27, 2014 at 01:30 pm.
Plea hearing on October 13, 2014 at 01:30 pm.
Plea hearing on September 15, 2014 at 01:30 pm.
Status conference on July 28, 2014 at 11:00 am.
Matousek FTA for waiver of preliminary hearing.  To be rescheduled.
Waiver of Prelim on July 7, 2014 at 10:45 am.

Defendant shall not consume any alcohol unless a physician states in writing that the defendant is alcohol dependent and complete withdrawal could endanger the defendant's health or life. In this case a doctor's excuse must be submitted to the Jackson County Clerk of Court or the Jackson County Jail within 48 hours of the bond being signed. Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, bar areas of restaurants, or where available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.  As a condition of your release, you must be available 24 hours per day, 7 days a week to submit to testing for alcohol when requested by a law enforcement officer or your probation agent. The defendant may submit to an alcohol test at the Jackson County Sheriff's Office or submit to a PBT by a law enforcement officer. Upon request, the defendant shall appear for and submit to testing within two (2) hours of the official's request. Not to possess or control of any weapons while on bond.
